metadata.case_name: Jyoti Pershad v. Administrator for the Union Territory of Delhi & Ors.

facts.text: Petitioner Jyoti Pershad is the owner of a house in Delhi in which respondents 3 to 11 were tenants, each occupying a single room.
Petitioner considered the house old and required to be demolished and reconstructed, submitted a plan to the Delhi Municipal Committee and applied for sanction.
Plan sanctioned by Delhi Municipal Committee for double-storeyed building with twelve rooms.

Petitioner filed suits against nine tenants under s.13(1)(g) of Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act, 1952, proving sanctioned plan providing accommodation and sufficient funds deposited in State Bank of India.
Civil Court in Delhi passed decrees in favour of petitioner for eviction of respondents 3 to 11 on December 8, 1956.
Tenants refused to deliver possession within three months as per s.15 of Rent Control Act, appealed to Senior Sub-Judge, Delhi under s.34.
Appeals disposed of against tenants by end of October 1957, some on merits, some by abatement.
Sanction lapsed due to rule requiring completion within one year from sanction.
Slum Areas (Improvement and Clearance) Act, 1956 (Central Act 96 of 1956) enacted and came into force in Delhi area.
New rules altered sanctions: double-storeyed buildings not permitted in the area; reconstructed building could only have three living rooms.
Tenants lost statutory right under s.15 Rent Control Act due to failure to quit within time fixed.
Petitioner filed nine applications under s.19 Slum Act before competent authority for eviction on ground building dilapidated and to be reconstructed.
Applications dismissed by competent authority on January 13, 1958, as 1956 sanction expired; option to revive if fresh sanction obtained.
Petitioner obtained fresh sanction for one-floor building with three living rooms.
Renewed applications under s.19 dismissed on July 30, 1958: tenants poor, old, low rent, hardship if evicted; landlord has other houses.
Appeals to Administrator under s.20 Slum Act dismissed: property not dilapidated/unfit; would lead to eviction of poor from slums.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.19(3) of Slum Areas (Improvement and Clearance) Act, 1956 vests unguided, unfettered power in competent authority, offending Art.14.
Whether s.19(3) involves excessive delegation of legislative power.
Whether s.19 constitutes unreasonable restriction on right to hold property under Art.19(1)(f), not saved by Art.19(5).

petitioner_arguments.text: S.19(3) vests unguided, unfettered power in executive officer to withhold permission to execute decree obtained after satisfying Rent Control Act, arbitrary and offends Art.14.
Power under s.19(3) is excessive delegation of legislative power.
Vesting power in executive to override property rights indefinitely without guidance is unreasonable restraint under Art.19(1)(f), not saved by Art.19(5); double restriction on Rent Control Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.19(1)(f), 19(5); s.13, s.38 Rent Control Act

respondent_arguments.text: Discretion under s.19 guided by policy and purpose in preamble and operative provisions of Act: improvement/clearance of slums and protection of tenants from eviction.
Guidance from context of Act, including Delhi Development Act 1957; restriction temporary till alternative accommodation.

court_reasoning.text: Art.14 not violated: policy guidance from preamble (improvement/clearance of slums, tenant protection) and provisions (declaration of slums, improvement/clearance/redevelopment); rational relation to object of orderly slum elimination with interim protection.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Enough guidance in Act; not unguided arbitrary power.

court_reasoning.text: No excessive delegation: legislature indicated policy; not necessary to detail every application.

Reasonable restriction under Art.19(5): in interests of general public (slum-dwellers' health/morals affect community); temporary (till slums eliminated via schemes); safeguards (hearing, inquiry, appeal); context of post-partition population influx.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Restriction has rational connection to object; not excessive.

court_reasoning.text: S.19 operates notwithstanding Rent Control Act due to non-obstante clauses; applies post-decree.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Special enactment prevails in slum areas.

holdings.text: S.19 Slum Act constitutionally valid; not violative of Art.14.
No excessive delegation of legislative power under s.19(3).
Restriction under s.19 reasonable under Art.19(5) in interests of general public.

precedents_cited.relevance: Summarised principles of Art.14 in 5 propositions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harishankar Bagla v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Legislature must declare policy; no unconstitutional delegation if standard provided.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dwarka Prasad Laxmi Narain v. State of Uttar Pradesh
State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Classification must have reasonable relation to object.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kathi Raning Rawat v. State of Saurashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Guidance from preamble, circumstances; policy indicated suffices.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kedar Nath Bajoria v. State of West Bengal
Pannalal Binjraj v. Union of India

statutes_cited.name: Slum Areas (Improvement and Clearance) Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Impugned provision requiring permission for eviction in slum areas; policy of improvement, clearance, tenant protection.

statutes_cited.name: Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Grounds for eviction (rebuilding); tenant reinstatement; non-obstante clause overridden by Slum Act.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction invoked; equal protection; right to property and reasonable restrictions.

statutes_cited.name: Delhi Development Act, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Master Plan to reduce slums; indicates temporary nature of restriction.

outcome.summary: Petitions under Art.32 challenging constitutionality of s.19 Slum Act dismissed; section held valid, not violative of Arts.14 or 19(1)(f). Court not concerned with specific orders but general validity.

key_quotes.text: The preamble describes the Act as one enacted for two purposes (1) the improvement and clearance of slum areas in certain Union Territories, and (2) for the protection of tenants in such areas from eviction.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: So long therefore as a building can, without great detriment to health or safety, permit accommodation, the policy of the enactment would seem to suggest that the slum dweller should not be evicted unless alternative accommodation could be obtained for him.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains application of policy to eviction permission.

key_quotes.text: The restrictions imposed cannot be said to be unreasonable.
key_quotes.speaker: court
